title: Meet Jaime and Luis Moreno Jr: the men who turned South America into Carolina Panthers fans…
text:
Jaime Moreno wears his heart on his sleeve. His commentary style is more futbal than American football.

Since 2010, Moreno and his nephew Luis Moreno Jr, have been calling Carolina Panthers games.

Luis is the Xs and Os guy. Jaime is the X-Factor guy. Together they are responsible for turning swathes of South America and the wider world into Panthers fans.

Jaime and Luis Moreno Jr have been calling Carolina Panthers games for the past nine seasons

Non-Spanish speakers listen to their radio broadcasts, such is their appeal. Head coach Ron Rivera’s parents tune in from Puerto Rico. Ahead of games, Rivera plays their calls to players to pump up the team.

Their clips reach three million hits in a little over a day. They dance, they sing, they are joyous, frequently funny and loud. Sometimes extremely so. And they celebrate everything. From the coin toss to a sack, it’s all there. Jaime has been known to say the word ‘touchdown’ twenty times in jubilation.

Four years ago, the duo went viral after Jaime’s description of quarterback Cam Newton’s front flip touchdown against the Houston Texans.

To translate: ’He’s getting in!’ Jaime bellows. ‘You’re flying like Superman, my dear dinosaur! Fly like you can, fly like you can! Touchdown! Touchdown! Touchdown! Touchdown! Dance, dance, dance my dear dinosaur! The Panthers add six more points to the score!’

And then there are the nicknames. Newton, who has a metatarsal injury and has not travelled to England, is El Dinosaurio (‘He’s one of a kind. There are no more like him,’ Jaime says).

There are many more. ‘Christian McCaffrey has a nickname. I call him The Locomotor,’ Jaime explains.

Christian McCaffrey is in sensational form and is the best running-back in the NFL right now

‘He carries the team. You put the team on his back, he’s like a train. No matter how the game is going he always tries to keep pushing, pushing pushing. What he did on Sunday proves that at this particular moment he’s the best running back in the league.’

'We call Luke Kuechly The Confessor,’ Jaime continues. ‘In medieval times, if you don’t speak and you don’t tell the truth they send you to the confessor. And he will put you in a room and he will tie you up and hit you so hard that you will come out with the truth. And that’s Luke Kuechly on the field.

‘If you try to pass where he’s at, he’s going to make you confess your sins. He’s going to hit you so hard that you don’t even know what’s going on. He’s just recorded his 1,000th tackle, so that’s a great asset for the team and a great accomplishment.’

And what of back-up quarterback Kyle Allen, whose record is played four, won four, including last season’s week 17 win against the New Orleans Saints?

‘He is The Galactico. He is from another galaxy. He came out of nowhere,’ Jaime says.

‘OK. He was always from the darkest part of the locker room. Nobody even talked to him, nobody said anything to him. Last year he came, we played in New Orleans at the Mercedes-Benz Dome and he came that week Ron Rivera made the decision. Allen went there and he did very good.

‘And then when Cam is hurt and Allen came aboard he started doing his homework. The most important thing to do is manage the game. One of the things I noticed, personally, when he’s been on the field, we have never been penalised for delay of game.

'He knows where he’s at, he knows where the clock is running he when to make a call. He knows when to stop the clock. It is something that he adds into the game but it’s still something Cam Newton needs to develop.’

In the absence of starting quarterback Cam Newton, Kyle Allen has stepped up to the plate

Jaime played American football at college in his native Mexico and moved to Carolina in 1989. He was obsessed with the NFL but his passion was often met with blank stares from his soccer-loving compatriots.

He started a radio show and invited Luis - another former player in Mexico - on to break down plays. After commentating on video games together, the pair had a certain shtick, but it wasn’t until a meeting with Panthers broadcast coordinator in 2009 that their dream became a reality.

Back then they pointed to the success of the Arizona Cardinals and Dallas Cowboys’ Spanish broadcasts.

The Panthers took a punt on the pair, and nowadays 16 NFL teams provide Spanish commentary.

None are more popular than the Morenos, who have had highs and lows at Carolina, who went 2-14 in their first year.

The 2015 season was a seesaw ride, with Carolina going 15-1 on their way to Super Bowl 50. The game ended in a punishing 24-10 defeat by the Denver Broncos.

Newton fell at the final hurdle, losing Super Bowl 50 to Peyton Manning's Denver Broncos

‘Going back to the hotel. We were on the bus. Nobody. Nobody. Nobody was talking, If you drop a piece of paper on the bus, I think you would feel when the piece of paper hit the floor,’ Jaime says.

‘It was a game that we planned to win and the team was completely ready to do it. But sometimes these things happen.

‘Denver were very experienced. That day Mike Tolbert had never dropped a pass - he dropped a pass. He always converts first downs. This day, he couldn’t do it.

‘Those are the things that didn’t click at the Super Bowl. I always say to win a Super Bowl you don’t have to play to win. You have to be ready to pass over the team that you are playing against.

‘This time this team was Denver. They controlled the momentum, they controlled the clock. Even though we dominated the game. Having the quarterback they had, it really made a big difference.

Linebacker Luke Kuechly is referred to as 'The Confessor' by the Morenos in their commentary

‘You know what I think, I think the Panthers will be back to the Super Bowl pretty soon. With this team we have I think the Panthers will be fighting for a Super Bowl pretty soon.’

The Panthers play the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in an NFC South battle at Tottenham Hotspur Stadium on Sunday. They are 3-2, buoyed by a feisty 34-27 win over the Jacksonville Jaguars, their third in a row.

‘Man, it was wonderful. It was not just a win. I think the way that they win is what counts a lot. Even thought the team make a lot of mistakes, the team as a whole was able to come out with a win.

'The most important thing was it wads the first win at home in the season. On top of that we hadn’t won at home for ten months. It was meaningful for the team and for the fans too,’ Jaime claims.

Jaime emphasised the need to put on a show for the viewers, not just simply call play-by-play

Asked to describe his style, Jaime says: ‘Listen. Walk away from the box. Don’t be a regular commentator who just calls the game. You have to have a show. Where people can laugh. When you’re laughing, they’re laughing. When you’re singing, they sing.

‘If I go there and just call the game the way it is, I don’t think I’m doing my job. I have go there and really entertain. Not just the fans. Myself - and I tell you - the players.

'Because Ron Rivera will play these quotes to the players so they listen to it on Saturday and they just laugh. They are funny moments for them.’

The Morenos will be calling Sunday’s game against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers from their booth at Bank of America Stadium. To listen to their commentary, visit www.panthers.com and select Spanish commentary.
